data.title: Save/load screen retention glitch
data.body:
Updating to 6.99.12.3.2123 from (somewhere in the region of; sorry I couldn't be more specific) 6.99.8, most likely sometime after that, has introduced a buggy change in behaviour regarding screens and saving/loading a game. Namely, if the game is saved on a say statement immediately following the hiding of a screen, upon loading the screen may be briefly visible and re-play any 'on hide' animations, sometimes multiple times, or maybe even remain stuck on the screen. This has been noted to happen in two different scenarios so far:

1) Calling a screen (A) which uses another (B). B is modal and has actions to Return(), thus resuming dialogue. On "hide", B has some disappearing animations for its constituents and also plays a sound. If the game is saved and loaded on the statement immediately afterwards, these disappearing animations replay and the sound is played 5-6 times rapidly.

2) A 'pause menu' style screen is modal and adds a translucent black image across the screen, with an imagemap on top (saving is done from here). If the menu is opened, closed, and then reopened again in order to save (on the same say statement), reloading the game causes the modal translucent background to be visible (the imagemap is not, but the modality still prevents dismissal). From what I can tell, the behaviour of this is less consistent than above: reloading the slot multiple times may see it not happen at all, or sometimes happen but only for a second or two.

This definitely started happening only after an update to Ren'Py, so it can't be my code - unless it's a result of deliberate engine changes I need to account for.

data.title: Possibility to mark variable for forced save
data.body:
**Preface**
Probably everyone who made a decent game with RenPy is aware that RenPy does not save (includes into game save file) variables that have same value. To check if value is same Renpy just checks if object is same or not via Python "is" operator ([see `get_changes()` in python.py](https://github.com/renpy/renpy/blob/67c893fb41089c24b6b572b10cedf26b134aff3a/renpy/python.py#L121)). That works fine for numbers and strings but anything more complex (like lists, sets, custom object) is not saved even if the object was modified.

Example:
```RenPy
init:
    define inventory = ['rusty_sword']
label add_shield:
    $ inventory.append('wooden_shield')
```
If you modify the list by calling `add_shield` and then try to save a game the list will not be saved because the object reference is same as before. After game load the list value will be `['rusty_sword']`.

Common workaround for this problem is to move declaration of such variables to a labels that executes after game `start`.
```RenPy
label init_variables:
    $ inventory = ['rusty_sword']
    return
label add_shield:
    $ inventory.append('wooden_shield')
label start:
    call init_variables
    jump real_start
```
Problems with this workaround:
- This makes game initialization sequence more complex.
- This forces you to put initialization of some variables to different places. Not to the places where it's logical to define certain variable.
- There is no initial value (value that is accessible before `start`). This causes issues if you plan to use something like `renpy.call_replay` (you have to reproduce initialization).

**Suggestion**
Add a way to explicitly mark a variable to be included in save file.
Probably the best if we had
1. a keyword to mark such variables, like "persist"
```RenPy
init:
    define persist inventory = ['rusty_sword']
```
2. RenPy python API method. Something like `add_to_persist`:
```RenPy
init:
    define inventory = ['rusty_sword']
    $ renpy.add_to_persist('inventory')
```

Note: keyword and method name are just examples.

Note: there a way to achieve same as 2 in RenPy already via
`renpy.game.log.ever_been_changed['NAME_OF_MY_VARIABLE'] = True`
however it's not part of public API so it's kind evil.

data.title: Slow text unexpectedly dismissed when what_args["slow_abortable"] is False
data.body:
Not sure if this is intended behavior, so I apologize if it is.

If a character has slow text but slow_abortable is False, then clicking will cause the dismiss event and advance to the next line of script, even while the slow text is not finished being displayed.

It seems like `what_args["slow_abortable"] = False` should suppress the dismiss event until the text is finished displaying.

Here is a proposed change in `text/text.py`.

Current:
```python
    def event(self, ev, x, y, st):
        """
        Space, Enter, or Click ends slow, if it's enabled.
        """

        if self.slow and renpy.display.behavior.map_event(ev, "dismiss") and self.style.slow_abortable:
            self.call_slow_done(st)
            self.slow = False
            raise renpy.display.core.IgnoreEvent()
```

New:
```python
    def event(self, ev, x, y, st):
        """
        Space, Enter, or Click ends slow, if it's enabled.
        """

        if self.slow and renpy.display.behavior.map_event(ev, "dismiss"):
            if self.style.slow_abortable:
                self.call_slow_done(st)
                self.slow = False
            raise renpy.display.core.IgnoreEvent()
```

data.title: RenPy freezes when drawing specific canvas lines
data.body:
While implementing a custom displayable for drawing some visuals I noticed that certain coordinates will cause the application (and the drawing code) to hang up and freeze. The simplest test case is this:

        def render(self, width, height, st, at):
            render = renpy.Render(10, 10)
            canvas = render.canvas()
            canvas.line("ff0", (0.0, 0), (0, 0)) #Works
            canvas.aaline("ff0", (0.0, 0), (0, 0)) #Works
            canvas.line("ff0", (0.9, 0), (0, 0)) #Hangs
            canvas.aaline("ff0", (0.9, 0), (0, 0)) #Works
            canvas.lines("ff0", False, [(0.9, 0), (0, 0)]) #Hangs

Only .line() and .lines() seem to be affected, interestingly .aaline() works fine.

Might be some kind of floating point rounding issue that causes an infinite loop in the drawing code? I guess it might be caused by the underlying Pygame rather than RenPy itself.

Rounding all coordinates to ints before passing them to the drawing code seems to fix the issue, but it would be nice not to have to worry about that.

data.title: Seamless audlo does not loop during the fadeout period.
data.body: Right now, if we hit the end of a song during the fadeout period, the fadeout immediately ends and we move on to the next track. This should be changed (perhaps on a channel-by-channel basis) so that the looping continues until the fadeout stops, at which point the next track is started.
